content.title: Magnetic Attraction and Repulsion
content.content:
### In this lesson
- You will learn how magnets interact with one another through their invisible fields.
- This applies to any installation scenario involving motors, relays, or solenoids where magnetic forces are harnessed.
- Key takeaways include the identification of poles, the fundamental law of interaction, and the directional nature of magnetic forces.

**What this is**
Magnetism is a physical phenomenon produced by the motion of electric charge, resulting in attractive and repulsive forces between objects. Every magnet possesses a **magnetic-pole** at each end—specifically a North pole and a South pole. These poles are the specific regions where the magnetic field is most concentrated and powerful. In the context of electrical installation, understanding these poles is essential because many components rely on the physical movement caused by these invisible forces to open or close contacts or rotate shafts.

**Why it matters**
As an electrician, you will encounter magnetism daily. Components like contactors and relays use an electromagnet to pull a set of contacts closed. If you do not understand how a **magnetic-pole** behaves, you cannot fully grasp how a motor generates torque or how a circuit breaker trips under fault conditions. The principles of attraction and repulsion are the foundation for nearly all electromechanical energy conversion in modern electrical systems.

**Key facts / rules**
- Every magnet has exactly two poles: North and South.
- The **law-of-magnetic-poles** dictates the interaction between two magnets.
- Like poles (North-North or South-South) will always repel each other.
- Unlike poles (North-South) will always attract each other.
- Magnetic field lines are typically represented as flowing from the North pole to the South pole externally.
- The force of attraction or repulsion becomes significantly stronger as magnets are moved closer together.

**How to recognise it**
To describe the principles of magnetic attraction and repulsion between poles, you must identify the physical reaction between two magnetic bodies. On the diagram, notice that the **magnetic-pole** labels indicate where the magnetic field lines are most densely packed, which is where you would feel the strongest pull or push. In a practical scenario, if you attempt to bring two North poles together, you will feel a distinct resistance or "pushing away" sensation; this is the **law-of-magnetic-poles** in action. Conversely, if a North pole is brought near a South pole, they will snap together with an attractive force. This physical "snap" or "push" is the primary way to recognise which type of interaction is occurring.

**Common mistakes**
Learners often confuse a **magnetic-pole** with an electric charge; a **magnetic-pole** always exists in a North-South pair within a magnet, whereas an electric charge can exist as a single positive or negative entity. Another common error is assuming that all metals will be attracted to a magnet; in reality, only ferromagnetic materials like iron, steel, nickel, and cobalt typically exhibit strong magnetic properties.

**Key Points**
- Magnets always have a North and a South **magnetic-pole**.
- The **law-of-magnetic-poles** states that opposites attract and likes repel.
- Magnetic forces are strongest at the poles and weaken with distance.
- These principles allow for the operation of motors and switchgear.

**Quick recap**
Magnets interact based on the orientation of their poles. By applying the **law-of-magnetic-poles**, we know that opposite poles pull together while identical poles push apart. This fundamental interaction is what drives the mechanical movement in many electrical devices we install and maintain.

### Coming Up Next
Now that we understand how magnets push and pull, we will look at how to measure the total amount and the concentration of that magnetic force.

content.title: Magnetic Flux vs. Flux Density
content.content:
### In this lesson
- You will learn to distinguish between the total amount of magnetism and how concentrated that magnetism is.
- This is used when evaluating the efficiency of transformers or the strength of magnetic sensors in an installation.
- Key takeaways include the definitions of flux and flux density, their respective SI units, and how area affects magnetic intensity.

**What this is**
When we quantify magnetism, we use two distinct but related terms. **Magnetic-flux** refers to the total number of magnetic field lines produced by a magnet or an electromagnet. It is the "whole amount" of magnetism present. **Magnetic-flux-density**, on the other hand, describes how many of those field lines pass through a specific unit of area. It tells us how "squashed together" or concentrated the magnetic field is at a particular point.

**Why it matters**
In electrical engineering, the concentration of magnetism is often more important than the total amount. For example, in a transformer core, we need a high **magnetic-flux-density** to transfer energy efficiently between windings. If the flux is too spread out, the device becomes bulky and inefficient. Understanding the difference helps electricians understand why certain components are shaped the way they are and why the cross-sectional area of a magnetic core is a critical design factor.

**Key facts / rules**
- **Magnetic-flux** is the total quantity of the magnetic field.
- The SI unit for **magnetic-flux** is the **weber** (Wb).
- **Magnetic-flux-density** is the amount of flux per unit area (measured in square metres).
- The SI unit for **magnetic-flux-density** is the **tesla** (T).
- One **tesla** is equivalent to one **weber** per square metre (1 T = 1 Wb/m²).
- If the same amount of flux is squeezed into a smaller area, the density increases.

**How to recognise it**
To explain the conceptual difference between magnetic flux and magnetic flux density, imagine a showerhead. The total amount of water coming out is like the **magnetic-flux**, measured in the **weber**. If you use a wide showerhead, the water is spread out; if you use a narrow nozzle, the water is high-pressure and concentrated, which is like a high **magnetic-flux-density** measured in the **tesla**. When we classify simple magnetic scenarios, we look at the focus: a large, weak refrigerator magnet has a certain amount of flux spread over a wide area (low density), whereas a small, powerful neodymium magnet might have less total flux but concentrates it into a tiny point (high density). On the diagram, the **magnetic-flux** is represented by the total number of lines, while the **magnetic-flux-density** is shown by how close those lines are to each other.

**Common mistakes**
Learners often confuse **magnetic-flux** with **magnetic-flux-density**; **magnetic-flux** is the total amount of magnetism produced by a source (the "quantity"), whereas **magnetic-flux-density** describes how concentrated that magnetism is over a specific area (the "intensity"). Another mistake is mixing up the units; remember that Wb is for the total and T is for the density.

**Key Points**
- **Magnetic-flux** (Wb) is the total field; **magnetic-flux-density** (T) is the concentration.
- Area is the deciding factor between the two: Density = Flux / Area.
- A high **tesla** rating indicates a very strong, concentrated magnetic field.
- A high **weber** rating indicates a large total magnetic output.

**Quick recap**
Flux is the total amount of magnetism, measured in **weber**, while flux density is how concentrated that magnetism is, measured in **tesla**. By changing the area through which the flux passes, we can increase or decrease the density, which is a core principle in the design of electrical machines.

### Coming Up Next
We have covered the basics of permanent magnets and their measurements; next, we will explore how electricity can be used to create magnetism on demand.

questions.questionText: An electrician is mounting two magnetic sensors. If the sensors are positioned so that identical poles face each other, what physical force will be exerted between them?
questions.hint: Like poles push away from each other.

questions.questionText: A magnetic lifting tool is used to pick up steel plates. If the tool's total magnetic flux remains constant but the contact area is reduced by half, what specific magnetic property has been increased?
questions.hint: Consider the concentration of the field lines as the area gets smaller.

questions.questionText: Identify the SI unit used to measure the total quantity of magnetism produced by a source, before considering the area it covers.
questions.hint: This unit is represented by the symbol Wb.

questions.questionText: Explain how the interaction of magnetic flux lines determines whether two magnets will move toward or away from each other. In your answer, include: (1) the direction flux lines travel between poles, (2) the behavior of flux when like poles meet, (3) the behavior of flux when opposite poles meet. (2-3 sentences)
keyPoints: Identifies that magnetic flux lines flow from the North pole to the South pole.
Explains that like poles (N-N or S-S) cause flux lines to push against each other, creating repulsion.
Explains that opposite poles (N-S) allow flux lines to flow from one magnet into the other, creating attraction.
Links the physical movement of the magnets to the interaction of their invisible magnetic fields.
Uses correct terminology such as flux, attraction, and repulsion.
expectedAnswer: Magnetic flux lines travel from the North pole to the South pole of a magnet. When like poles meet, these lines push against each other to cause repulsion, whereas opposite poles allow the flux lines to join together, resulting in magnetic attraction.

Flux lines always move from North to South; when like poles are brought together, the flux lines conflict and repel each other. Conversely, opposite poles attract because the flux lines can flow continuously from the North pole of one magnet to the South pole of the other.
questions.hint: Think about the direction of the lines of force and what happens when those lines either clash or combine.

questions.questionText: Describe how the physical force of attraction between two magnets is influenced by both the total quantity of magnetism and its concentration. In your answer, include: (1) the law of magnetic attraction, (2) the definition of magnetic flux, (3) the definition of flux density, (4) how concentrating flux affects the force between poles. Answer in 3-4 sentences OR concise bullet points.
keyPoints: States the law of attraction (opposite poles attract while like poles repel).
Defines magnetic flux as the total number of magnetic field lines (measured in Webers).
Defines flux density as the amount of flux passing through a specific unit area (measured in Teslas).
Explains that force is determined by both the total flux and how tightly packed those lines are.
Notes that reducing the area (increasing flux density) results in a stronger magnetic force.
Connects flux density directly to the perceived 'strength' of the attraction or repulsion.
Demonstrates the relationship between area, flux, and density (B = Φ / A).
Synthesizes the concepts to show that high flux density at the poles creates the strongest physical interaction.
expectedAnswer: The law of magnetic attraction states that opposite poles pull together, a force driven by magnetic flux, which is the total quantity of magnetic field lines. Flux density measures how concentrated these lines are over a specific area; therefore, by concentrating a high volume of flux into a small surface area, the flux density increases, resulting in a significantly stronger force of attraction.

• Attraction occurs between opposite poles (North and South).
• Magnetic flux represents the total number of magnetic lines, while flux density measures how many lines exist per square meter.
• When flux is concentrated into a smaller area, the flux density increases.
• This higher flux density creates a more powerful magnetic force between the two poles.
questions.hint: Consider how the total amount of magnetism (flux) and the area it covers (density) work together to change the strength of the pull between opposite poles.
